Lebesgue differentiation theorem

Let I=I0,0=[0,1]I = I_{0,0} = \br{0, 1}I=I0,0​=[0,1] be the unit interval, and for n=0,1,2,…,n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots,n=0,1,2,…, and 0≤j≤2n−10 \leq j \leq 2^n - 10≤j≤2n−1 let

In,j=[j2−n,(j+1)2−n].I_{n,j} = \br{j2^{-n}, \p{j+1}2^{-n}}.In,j​=[j2−n,(j+1)2−n].

For f∈L1(I,dx)f \in L^1\p{I, \diff{x}}f∈L1(I,dx) define

Enf(x)=∑j=02n−1(2n∫In,jf dt)χIn,j(x).E_nf\p{x} = \sum_{j=0}^{2^n-1} \p{2^n\int_{I_{n,j}} f \,\diff{t}}\chi_{I_{n,j}}\p{x}.En​f(x)=j=0∑2n−1​(2n∫In,j​​fdt)χIn,j​​(x).

Prove that if f∈L1(I,dx)f \in L^1\p{I, \diff{x}}f∈L1(I,dx) then lim⁡n→∞Enf(x)=f(x)\lim_{n\to\infty} E_nf\p{x} = f\p{x}limn→∞​En​f(x)=f(x) almost everywhere on III.
Solution.

Let xxx be a Lebesgue point of fff, i.e., a point where the Lebesgue differentiation theorem applies. Because the {In,j}j\set{I_{n,j}}_j{In,j​}j​ partition III for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, there exists j(n,x)j\p{n,x}j(n,x) such that x∈In,j(n,x)x \in I_{n,j\p{n,x}}x∈In,j(n,x)​ for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1.

Notice that this collection shrinks nicely to xxx: In,j(n,x)⊆B(x,21−n)I_{n,j\p{n,x}} \subseteq B\p{x, 2^{1-n}}In,j(n,x)​⊆B(x,21−n) and if mmm denotes the Lebesgue measure on III,

m(In,j(n,x))=12−n>14⋅12n−1=m(B(x,21−n))4.m\p{I_{n,j\p{n,x}}} = \frac{1}{2^{-n}} > \frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{2^{n-1}} = \frac{m\p{B\p{x, 2^{1-n}}}}{4}.m(In,j(n,x)​)=2−n1​>41​⋅2n−11​=4m(B(x,21−n))​.

Thus, the Lebesgue differentiation theorem applies:

∣Enf(x)−f(x)∣=∣2n∫In,j(n,x)f dt−f(x)∣=∣1m(In,j(n,x))∫In,j(n,x)f(t)−f(x) dt∣≤1m(In,j(n,x))∫In,j(n,x)∣f(t)−f(x)∣ dt,\begin{aligned} \abs{E_nf\p{x} - f\p{x}} &= \abs{2^n \int_{I_{n,j\p{n,x}}} f \,\diff{t} - f\p{x}} \\ &= \abs{\frac{1}{m\p{I_{n,j\p{n,x}}}} \int_{I_{n,j\p{n,x}}} f\p{t} - f\p{x} \,\diff{t}} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{m\p{I_{n,j\p{n,x}}}} \int_{I_{n,j\p{n,x}}} \abs{f\p{t} - f\p{x}} \,\diff{t}, \end{aligned}∣En​f(x)−f(x)∣​=∣∣​2n∫In,j(n,x)​​fdt−f(x)∣∣​=∣∣​m(In,j(n,x)​)1​∫In,j(n,x)​​f(t)−f(x)dt∣∣​≤m(In,j(n,x)​)1​∫In,j(n,x)​​∣f(t)−f(x)∣dt,​

which tends to 000 as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞, by the Lebesgue differentiation theorem. Thus, because the Lebesgue differentiation theorem applies for almost every xxx, it follows that Enf(x)→n→∞f(x)E_nf\p{x} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} f\p{x}En​f(x)n→∞​f(x) almost everywhere, as required.
